content: - herringbone double_crochet blo - back loop only decrease - decrease 2 stitches together invj - invisible join ❖ i really hate the visible noticeable seam that results from slip stitching row closed so i always join row with an invisible join - never a slip_stitch ➢ when you get to the last stitch of the row and you are ready to join drop the loop on your hook insert the hook from back to front into both loops of the the joining stitch which will be the first stitch of every round pick up the working loop and pull it through this will create an invisible seam don t pull it through tightly - this is the first stitch of the next round you don t want it to disappear for pulling through too tightly and you need to get the hook and a stitch in there the chain 1 at the beginning of the round never counts as a stitch let s begin ribbing i like the ribbing to be around 2 inches wide this is easily changeable to be whatever you want just do more or fewer chains in the starting chain and then continue from row 2 row 1 with the larger hook chain 7 5 switch to smaller hook single_crochet in 2nd chain from hook and in each chain across 6 4 ch1 turn row 2 working in blo single_crochet in each st across 6 4 chain 1 turn the easy escapade beanie by amy drossner copyright © november 2021 3 row 3 - 40/32 repeat row 2 add or subtract the number of row until the band is as long as you would like ensuring that you have an even number of row i end up with about a 15 inch length when laid flat and relaxed test out your length by holding it to your head and placing it around where it would sit if worn as a hat meeting the ends together there should be some stretch but still be comfortable not sliding down or binding too tightly for purposes of writing this pattern the instructions will indicate 40/32 row of ribbing resulting in 40/32 stitches in the initial rounds in the body if you did more or fewer row of ribbing your stitch count for the initial row of the body should match your number of row of ribbing tip with the even number of row you will end the last row on the side opposite the starting tail if you added or subtracted row you should still end on this opposite side it will help make the ribbing edge neater by being able to stitch over the tail and work it up into the body instead of into the finished edge of the ribbing be sure to have an even number of row once you have your ideal ribbing length and comfortable fit hold both ends together and working through both loops of the beginning row and the blo of
